column4: greets, not going to be pessimist but im switching to ubuntu from freebsd
for ffs why cant freebsd keep things simpler and have support for things
where do i edit my networking - cant find /etc/rc.conf
It's been awhile since I've used FBSD on a desktop, but it never seemed overly complicated to me.
You can't compare it to ubuntu/debian/rhel/centos.  You can compare it to arch linux, or crux however.
If you're using the desktop, use network manager, otherwise, /etc/network/interfaces
networkmanager is a gnome thing that ubuntu is fond of using for gui config.  On the desktop, it's best to stick with that and not use the files, as it can get confused.
Seriously?  gedit isn't part of the fbsd gnome desktop packages?
generally put a persons name followed by a colon, and the IRC client highlights it for that user.

Or for a private conversation, you use /msg, but generally that's frowned upon in help channels.  People like to hear what other people suggest, and add to it, suggest alternatives, correct the suggestions, etc.
Probably xbuntu then.  XFCE based ubuntu desktop, and since XFCE uses gnome, it's got just enough gnome for everything to run.
Well, ubuntu has it's own frustrations using X, as it autoconfigures everything, leaving you no xorg.conf to peruse and edit if you don't like something.
Heh, have fun, I generally turn off eyecandy, so I never know where to turn it on.
yes.  Unless you are the default gateway, of course.
I think so.  I don't have an example infront of me.   Just "gateway"
Pretty sure there's a good manpage on it.
